A trilocation.
What happened to that?
It is still the plan to move the Coombe Hospital to the St. James's site after we complete the project.
At what stage is that plan?
After we complete the current project, the Coombe would be moved to the St. James's site.
Will BAM do that also?
It will be an entirely separate project.

I return to the accounts and I will focus on the nitty-gritty of one or two matters. I asked about the rent and I quoted the wrong figure, about which the Comptroller and Auditor General rightly corrected me. The report makes reference to an office fit-out. The prices are colossal. In 2016, the office fit-out was estimated at approximately €594,000. Is that correct?
Yes.
In addition to the rent, there is a office fit-out, at more than €500,000, and then in 2017, there was another office fit-out estimated to cost €133,945. Will someone explain those figures?
I spoke previously about when we moved into the new offices in Herberton-----
Are the figures justified?

All the figures were tendered. The building we took over was a shell and core building that had planning permission for a different use. It comprised only four walls and a ceiling. We had to fit it out as a normal office and, therefore, we tendered the works and appointed a contractor to carry out the works.

Outside of the committee, we will pick up the consequences of this on the ground, as some of my colleagues have outlined. There have been references to the new model of care, where fewer children will be going to hospital. The damning reality is that fewer children will be going to hospital in other places because there will not be hospitals and projects will be stopped. I consider that in this context and I always consider it in terms of rent. Various organisations have appeared before the committee on the issue. Rent and the fit-out of an office were estimated at more than €500,000 in one year and, the following year, another €100,000 was estimated. Was there an alternative where money could have been saved rather than spending more than €500,000 on the fit-out of an office?

One great advantage of the location is that it has embedded the project in the community in which it will be based. Having the development board off site of the St. James's campus would have been a problem. As it is on the fringes of the St. James's site, it has been able to develop linkages with the community and involve it in the project.
I am not sure if that could justify the fit-out of an office costing €500,000.

I am not trying to justify the fit-out but the Deputy asked whether there was an alternative location. There were limited options in the immediate vicinity of St. James's, and it was the right decision to locate the development board in that vicinity.
At that cost?
Community gain is a key benefit of the project that we are seeking to realise.

Community gain. I will leave that matter.

There was another sentence I did not understand on page 19 of the report. It states, "Consultancy costs are all outsourced "Business-as-usual" functions." What does that mean?
We discussed that earlier.
I am sorry. I must have missed it. Did I arrive late?

I do not remember, but I explained that, on the statement on internal control, it is a power requirement that there be a disclosure in respect of consultancies. The nature of the consultancies that it was interested in having disclosed, however, were change management-type consultancies or special investigation-type consultancies, where the consultancy expenditure that is outlined in the report is normal for the nature of the business it does. It contracts designers, project managers, cost consultants and so on.
I missed that explanation.
That note appears in the statement of each public body. One will see it in other financial statements.
I had not seen it previously.
This is the first year of its appearance and it will be developed to try to provide better quality and more detailed information that is of interest to the committee.
The final matter in the accounts I wish to examine is legal costs.

It also appears on page 19, under the heading, "Legal Costs and Settlements", directly below the sentence which the Deputy read into the record. It is also one of the requirements under the code of practice.

The board will be able to explain the nature of this case.

This was in relation to the O'Reilly Avenue residents who bordered the campus. During the course of the construction works, when our contractors were replacing boundary walls, damage was caused to the residents' properties and we were brought to the High Court. These are the legal costs associated with that action.
What were the legal costs associated with the action?
A figure of €98,000 is noted for legal costs and settlements in the O'Reilly Avenue case.
Was the case settled or did it end up in court?
We have not returned to the High Court. We are working with the residents to conclude-----
Is it still an outstanding legal case? Has it yet been settled?
They may-----
I ask Mr. Pollock to listen to my question. Has it been settled or is it still open?
It is open for them to bring it back.
What is the €98,000 for?
It was for our legal costs associated with the High Court hearing.
But it has not yet been resolved.
We have a solution with the residents that we are progressing, but they-----
Mr. Pollock does not need to tell me the details. I understand he cannot do so, but has the matter been resolved?
It has not yet been resolved.
What is the anticipated cost of the case?
We are not anticipating more legal costs. There will be some reinstatement costs with the residents and we intend to recover them under project insurance policies.
Was it for damage done?
It was for damage caused.
Is it one case on behalf of a group of residents or is each resident taking a separate case?
They are together in one case.
Are there other cases?
No.
I would like to turn to the issue of the board. How many re on it?
Twelve.
How many are female?
Two.
How many are doctors?
One member is a clinical doctor.
Perhaps one of the board members will identify the board to the committee and tell us why they are on it?
My name is Tom Costello.
What is Mr. Costello's background?

My background is in construction. I have spent all of my career in it. Mr. Tom Bouchier-Hayes' background is in legal services. Mr. John Cole's background is in architecture. Previously he was head of Health Estates in Northern Ireland and brings a lot of experience. Mr. Brian Fitzgerald was previously CEO of St. James's Hospital.
Prior to that he was finance director.
Yes. Mr. Karl Kent is a planner and was previously on the board of An Bord Pleanála. With Mr. John Martin, he worked with Dublin City Council in planning-----
Mr. John Martin was a planner in Dublin City Council.

Yes. They provided huge guidance in steering us through a successful planning application. Mr. Paul Quinn is head of procurement in the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform, while Ms Anne Butler is a retired civil engineer. She was a member of the Institution of Engineers of Ireland.
Is she retired from the board or as an engineer?
She is a retired engineer. She was also on the board of the EPA.
I am sorry, but is she on the board or not?
Anne Butler is on the board.
What is her background?

She is a civil engineer and was and may currently be on the board of the Environmental Protection Agency. Ms Marguerite Sayers is a long-term employee of the ESB and until recently she head of EirGrid. Ms Hilary Hoey from the School of Paediatrics has been replaced by Professor Johnathan Hourihane. Mr. Liam Woods is from the HSE, while Mr. Lorcan Birthistle is the current CEO of St. James's Hospital.
I thank Mr. Costello and apologise for interrupting Deputy Connolly.
Is it a five-year term?
Indeed.
The current membership were all appointed in 2013 and then reappointed in 2018 by the Minister.
Correct.
Were they reappointed before the escalation in costs was brought to the attention of the Department?
Correct.
Therefore, the escalation in costs was brought to the attention of the Department following the appointment of the board members.
I am not sure of the exact date. It probably happened around the same time.
I think it was in July that the Minister would have made the appointments.
The escalation in costs was brought to the attention of the Department in August.

It might be worth saying because the Minister said on Tuesday at the health committee that by virtue of the Children's Health Ireland legislation which has just been passed by the Oireachtas, he has powers to reconstitute the board. He noted when he was reappointing the board that in the context of the implementation of the legislation, he reserved the right to look at the composition of the board.

That is, in a sense, an impossible task. PricewaterhouseCoopers, an accounting firm, is examining the matter, at a cost of €450,000. The witnesses should be telling us what went wrong, what governance arrangements were in place, what has been learned and so on. What I have learned from Mr. Costello and Mr. Pollock is that the details of the tender were a bit on the lean side, that they should have been clearer about that and the checks and balances. That is all I have heard from them on this matter. I have read the transcript of the proceedings at the heath committee and know all of the questions that were asked. I have read the 2015 script in which the witnesses were alerted to this difficulty. I feel sorry for the Department, except that it is the oversight body. Am I correct that practically all of the board members are from the private sector?
Mr. Paul Quinn and Mr. Liam Woods are not.
With the exception of one or two, the board members are from the private sector.
There are two-----

The vast majority are from the private sector, which supposedly is very good, more efficient and cost effective and the public service is dreadful. That is the message form all of this. The public service decided that it was not able for this project, that it was too complex and should be given to the experts. It set up a board and set itself the job of monitoring the project under the public spending code, with which the board is supposed to comply . All of the details are set out. I do not have the time to question the witnesses about all of these issues. They should be telling us which parts of the public spending code they did not comply with, why they did not do so and what they have learned. Instead, they are telling us that this is a marvellous project and so on, which is a waste of our time because we already know that. We all want a new children's hospital, but we want to know how the overrun occurred? The Department has been left to pick up the pieces. As I said, this is the private sector working for the public sector. Do the witnesses disagree with anything I have said?

I am anxious to summarise as quickly as possible. At the outset, when we were asked to join the board in 2013, the scope of the project was defined through the work about which we talked in the case of the Mater hospital. In overall terms, we were to build a hospital 125,000 sq. m in size.
The board was to plan, design, construct and equip it.

Yes, but at that stage, the clinical requirement was more or less defined because of the work done in the case of the Mater hospital. In essence, we were asked to deliver a hospital that would be of the order of 125,000 sq. m in size; therefore, what we were to deliver was pretty much defined. We had to design it in detail but, in essence, at a high level, the clinical needs, bedrooms, etc. had all been defined. Our job was to put a plan in place.

Mr. Costello can explain all of that to the Chairman on his time, but will he please tell me the point he is leading to? What changed? The members of the board were appointed as experts. They have repeatedly told us and the Joint Committee on Health about their backgrounds and how they are the experts. They were employed and I gather their money went up during this period. The money for Mr. Costello or Mr. Pollock went up. Is that right?
In the last year I took no money at all.
That is very good. Prior to that Mr. Costello was taking money and being paid. Is that right?
I was paid.
The money increased at a certain point. Is that correct?
In the first two years I was operating part-time so I was giving about two days per week to the hospital.

The board members were the experts. Here we are now. What I would expect from the experts is to go through the points by number - one, two, three and four. What I see is a load of reports. Mr. Farragher was the finance officer. The board had another private expert who came in. Was it someone from BDO Ireland? Is that person still with the board?
No.
At what point did that person go? Was it after Mr. Farragher joined?
They left shortly after we moved from the Mater site. They finished up what they were doing.

I will go back to a couple of practical questions. There is phase 1 and phase 2. The board signed a contract for phase 1. What was the date on that contract? When will it be completed? The board gave us a price this morning of €80 million or thereabouts. Can Mr. Pollock clarify the position on phase 1 or phase A for me?
We signed a contract in August 2017.
Was that for phase A?
It signs for both because the tender was awarded on phase A and phase B. I am trying to do my best to clarify this. The tender evaluation involved phases A and B. There was only one contract.
That is right.

The document stated: "We are instructing you to proceed with the phase A works, which is €84 million plus VAT". That brings the figure to approximately €100 million. We had the option either to proceed with phase B or not to proceed with phase B. That is the point we reached at the end of last year. The question was would we or would we not award the second phase.
Phase A was to do certain works, mostly under the ground.
That is correct.
There was some preliminary design for phase B included as well. Is that right?
Yes.
What was that? Is Mr. Pollock telling me there was no contract for that and it was simply part of an overall contract?
There is one contract but the contract sum had a sum for phase A works.
What was the sum for phase A?
It was approximately €84 million.
That is the figure plus VAT. Is that correct?
Yes.
There is a figure for the design for the second part – the preliminary design for phase B. What about that?

The total of phase A and phase B that the company tendered was €637 million. The figure for €84 million was for phase A and the rest was for phase B, which we could decide, subject to Government approval, to award or not.

I have two final questions. Who on the board represents the public purse? Who on the board represents doctors and nurses for the layout of the rooms and theatres and so on? The first question is about the public purse.

We are guided by the public spending code. In essence, clear guidelines are set out in terms of how we manage the project as well as the rules around procurement and so on. It is very clear. Then, we are audited on an annual basis. That shows that we are working within the code in place.

I will go back to the past six months when this became obvious in the beginning. There has been huge and intense work from the board and the executive to interrogate every euro of this. We put in place a number of reviews. First of all, the aim was to check where we identified the additional spending, especially for mechanical and electrical spending. The idea was to ensure that what we had designed was fit for purpose and to ensure that we were not over-designed. That is relevant for one of the reports and we can talk about it in a while. We set out to ensure that we got competitive rates in 2016 and to ensure they were applied to the updated quantities and, at the end of the day, to ensure we were paying for what we are getting. At the end of the day, the quantities have increased, but right now we are paying for what we are getting and we have the benefit of the competitive rates we got in 2016.
Were there not omissions in the design in the first place? Has the board not quantified the cost of the omissions?
There were omissions of €20 million. I am keen to give the committee a sense that the board has interrogated this deeply.
Is there any question of an indemnity being raised?

I want to explain one of these in order that people can understand it. The roof of the wards block is curved. There is a plant room in behind that. When the quantity surveyor was taking off the quantities - he is a mechanical and electrical surveyor - he understood there was a roof over that. In fact, it is an external plant. Given that fact, he did not include the aluminium cladding that is required to wrap duct work that is external. Given the scale of the job, that was nearly €4 million of an omission. We have gone through, line by line, every issue like that to understand how this happened. I am saying this so that the committee understands it. That was one particular example to give some understanding to it.
I asked about the doctors. Who represents the doctors and the medical profession?
The board is obviously appointed by the Minister but there has been a representative from the faculty of paediatrics from the start.
I saw that.

Professor Hilary Hoey is a paediatrician and Professor Jonathan Hourihane is professor of paediatrics in Cork. He is there now. Throughout the process, from the very beginning of the process, extraordinary demand has been placed on the clinicians and on non-clinical support staff in the three Dublin children hospitals in terms of getting them to engage with the project, the design, their needs and all of the room data sheets. Representatives from the three hospitals for children have sat in. They have been involved in every stage of the design.
Let us suppose someone says to me, as a politician, that the doctors have not been kept informed or consulted and that they are dissatisfied. Is that completely inaccurate?
I am sorry. I do not understand the question.
It is not a question. People have come to me and said that is not correct and that doctors are being ignored. They maintain their views and wishes are not being taken on board. Is that totally wrong?

No, first of all, everyone has been consulted. There have been groups and committees. We have worked with every specialty area. They have received drawings and plans. We have been back to talk to people. They have been into meetings. Clinicians were involved in terms of the detailed design. There has not always been agreement. Not everything that people asked for was granted. For example, a certain service may have wanted something in particular, but to have provided that would have compromised another service. The planning design of the hospital has to take into account how the whole hospital works. Something that might work for a particular service might in fact compromise future flexibility or adaptability. We have consulted closely with people. We have listened to people and met people, but there will be people who will be disappointed that things they wanted and asked for are not in the final design. That is all I can say about that, but there has been really extensive engagement.
At this stage I will call Deputy O'Brien.
I am keen to clarify the role of Mr. Paul Quinn. He was there on behalf of the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform. He sits on the board. Is that correct?

He is there in an individual capacity given his procurement expertise. That is one of the factors that indicated he is suitable for the job, but he is not there representing his employer. He is there in an individual capacity.
Is that not a conflict? He is a procurement specialist in the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform, which is the Department responsible for the public purse, and he is sitting on a board.
It is the biggest public sector procurement that will be undertaken. He is one of the recognised public sector procurement experts. The decision made at the time-----
He is there in a private capacity. Is that right?

He is there as an individual to bring his competency to the board. Had we ignored the opportunity to put someone with that competency on the board, we could have been judged not to have a fully competent board. The decision was made to use his skills.

If something is discussed at a board meeting that could affect the public purse, he is unable to report back to the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform because he is not there in his capacity as a Department of Public Expenditure and Reform official or employee. Is that correct?
The formal governance reporting lines still hold that the-----
I will get to them but I am asking this question.
The governance lines are the means by which the information is brought to the------
Three members were appointed to the board to represent the interests of the general public. Who were they? I ask the Chairman for extra time given that the answers are not coming promptly.
I will give the Deputy ten minutes.
That is fine and I might not even take them all.
We do not have the information categorised in that way. We will check it and get it straight to the Deputy. Perhaps the development board-----
I am sure the chair of the board should be able to tell me who the three members appointed to represent the interests of the general public were.
I would have to check that in fairness.
This is-----
I was given that information six years ago, so I would need to double check it.
You sat on a board with them for the past five years-----
We operate as a collective. It is a feature of the statutory instrument that certain people nominate and there are certain-----

The legislation states the membership of the board shall consist of 13 persons. The chairperson is appointed by the Minister, we know who that is, and 12 ordinary members are appointed by the Minister, three of whom are appointed to represent the interests of the general public and three others are appointed on the nomination of the chairperson and perhaps the chairperson will tell me who these three are.
They are Tim Bouchier Hayes
Tim Bouchier Hayes.
Let me just think-----

I think I have the answer subject to checking. Tom Costello, John Cole, Marguerite Sayers and Paul Quinn were appointed by the Minister. I take it that the three latter names are the public interest members. The chair nominated Karl Kent, John Martin and Tim Bouchier Hayes. The HSE nominated Lorcan Brithistle and Liam Woods. The Royal College of Physicians of Ireland nominated Professor Jonathan Hourihane and, before that, Professor Hilary Hoey. Tallaght Hospital nominated Brian Fitzgerald and the Children's University Hospital Temple Street nominated Anne Butler.
Mr. Paul Quinn was nominated by the Minister to protect the public interest.
Yes.
He is the procurement specialist in the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform.
Yes.
He is the head of the Office of Government Procurement-----
He is the head of the Office of Government Procurement.
Yes.

-----and he was put on the board to protect the public interest but if something arises at a board meeting he cannot report it back to the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform because it has to go through the formal reporting lines set out in legislation.
The Deputy asked me what I would expect and I would expect the formal governance lines to apply. I did not say he could not-----
Okay, so he can.
The board procedure would come into play as to whether matters were confidential. The normal governance lines are that the exchange of information would happen via the executive or the chair.

The reason I ask this is because we were told earlier the escalating costs were first brought to the attention of the board in June 2018. They were not brought to the attention of the Department of Health or the HSE until late August 2018. However, the head of procurement in the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform was sitting on the board aware of these escalating costs. He is on the board to protect the public interest but there was a two month delay from when the board first became aware of escalating costs to when the information was relayed to the Department of Health. Mr. Quinn is not here to answer but I have a presumption as to why the board made a decision to delay for two months before bringing the information to the knowledge of the Department and the HSE. The conspiracy theorist in me would ask whether it had anything to do with the reappointment of the board in July 2018. It became aware in June of escalating costs but it was not brought to anyone's attention until August and they were all reappointed in July. It is a fair question to ask.

It is absolutely a fair question. The Deputy has to understand the workings of the organisation in terms of a finance subcommittee and the board itself, the reporting structure upwards and being able to interrogate information before repeating it. The Deputy will appreciate that as soon as information is received from the professionals or the executive team we do not immediately rush off and state we have a problem. It is very important to remember that, at the same time, we were progressing with the contractors the definition of the determination of a guaranteed maximum price. The last thing in the world we wanted to do was to spread information that it was at a particular cost but we were not too sure where it was going and that it might go to a particular figure. There was a risk of that information becoming broadly known. It was a very sensitive time-----
Does Mr. Costello mean becoming public knowledge?
Absolutely.

Particularly in terms of that information being used by the contractors for their own benefit, in terms of having a sense of where we thought it was going. Protecting the reporting structure was really important at the time.

The reporting structure is also set out in legislation in terms of what information should be brought to the Minister. It speaks about relevant information being brought in an appropriate timely manner, and I will get to that in a couple of seconds.

In terms of the governance structure, a number of subcommittees were established by the executive board. There was the finance committee, the procurement subcommittee, the construction subcommittee and the finance subcommittee. I presume they had a very hands-on approach to procurement, financial controls and the management of the construction project. With regard to the reporting structure, if the executive board became aware in June 2018, is Mr. Costello stating that none of the subcommittees were aware prior to that? Was it the executive board that brought information to the attention of the subcommittees or did the subcommittees get the information first and bring it to the attention of the board?
Generally the finance subcommittee meetings are held a number of days before the board meetings. It could have been a number of days beforehand in June.
How many meetings did it have in 2018? I know there were 11 in 2017.
It was similar.
It was a similar number. To pin this down, is Mr. Costello now saying the finance subcommittee was aware of the escalating costs before the executive board was aware of them?
That is the structure we operate.

Mr. Costello probably does not have it but I would like to know the date the finance subcommittee first discussed the escalating cost. Since 10 a.m. today we have gone from late August 2018 to June 2018 to a time before the executive board became aware in 2018. I would like to know when the escalating costs were first brought to the attention of either the subcommittee or the executive board. It is important. For me it is very relevant information that, I would argue, under the legislation should have been passed on to the Minister in a very timely and an appropriate manner but it was not. Will Mr. Breslin tell me when the Minister become aware of it?

The Department became aware of it at the end of August - not of the extent of it, but that there was an emerging issue. The Minister was advised at the same time.
So it was late August.
Late August.

How did the finance sub-committee identify the escalating costs? Did somebody from the main contractors come to it and have a conversation? Was it done through meetings with it, letters or emails? How did the finance sub-committee become aware of it?

Each executive of the board presents to the finance sub-committee. The contractor is miles away from this. There is no contact with the board. The executive team reports and, in turn, is advised by the design team. In this case, Linesight acts as the financial adviser and cost consultant and reports to Mr. Pollock and his team.
Who is on the executive team?

Obviously, as the project director, I am part of the executive team. The design team would issue monthly reports to us regarding how the second phase GMP process was going. We then report to the finance sub-committee meetings. As Mr. Costello said, the board meetings are convened and the chair of the finance sub-committee would report-----
Mr. Pollock knew about the escalating costs before the executive board knew about them.
Can I clarify something? Escalating costs commenced in 2017 so at that stage-----
We are talking about the significant escalation of costs.
This is why I want to be clear. A figure of €60 million was identified in 2017.

I am leaving that aside. That is in the halfpenny place compared to what we are dealing with now. When would Mr. Pollock have first become aware of the significant escalation of costs - the difference between the 2017 and 2018 figures - or that there was an issue relating to it?
In respect of costs through the first six months of 2018, as reported by our design team, it was basically on budget - there or thereabouts.
So it was on budget up to June.

Without getting too technical, we have maybe 150 procurement packages that are signed off. The design team reports to say that it has now determined the final price for the doors and ceilings so trending is coming through. The trending coming through for the first six months of the year was basically there or thereabouts. It was in June when a further €40 million was identified. That is above the €60 million about which we spoke back in-----
So around €40 million was identified, which triggered alarm bells.
At that stage, we decided to get the design team in to make a detailed presentation.
When did it come in?
I would have to check the dates. It was July and we brought the figure of €200 million to the board in August. We briefed the HSE and the Department.
We have asked PwC to look at the escalation process and the early warning within that. This matter will be fully checked as part of the PwC exercise.

That is grand. Mr. Pollock became aware in June when the design team told him about an additional €40 million. It told him that the first six months were okay and all the procurement contracts were on schedule and coming in on price but that there was one with €40 million over and above. Mr. Pollock brought that to the attention of the executive board in-----
In June.
Following that, it was brought to the attention of the finance sub-committee by the executive board.
Yes.
The finance sub-committee would have looked at it then.

Yes. The board was aware of the figure of €60 million plus €40 million in June. The design team continued. It was at the end of July and the start of August when we had the €200 million. We apprised our board at that stage.
So it went from €40 million to €200 million between June and the end of August.
Correct.
When did it go from €200 million up to what it is today?
It was €200 million in August. We concluded the GMP process-----
In November.
Yes. We brought the final report to our board at the November board meeting.
It had gone up to €450 million.
Correct.
Were these just the construction costs or were they the project costs in total?
They were the project costs in total.

That was November. A number of reports were produced. Was the internal audit report by Mazars the one that identified the final escalating cost of the €450 million because that was completed in November 2018?
The board commissioned Mazars to carry out a review of what had occurred through the two-stage process, including who knew what and when in terms of reporting timelines.
Is that report public?
We can certainly make it available.

I would appreciate it if the report could be made available. Obviously, Mazars looked at the GMP process. It reported in November 2018. We know the figure escalated from August 2018 to November 2018, which is four months, at a rate of €100 million per month.
I can tell the Deputy that it was €100 million in June and €200 million in August.
And it was €450 million in November.
Correct.

So it was €100 million per month. That report would definitely be of interest to me and the rest of the committee because I presume it outlines why it went from being on track in June to €450 million in November.
Those issues are-----
They are addressed in the report.
Correct.

Why is PwC producing a report if a report is already there that identifies why the project went from being on track with regard to price to €450 million within the space of four or five months? What is the difference between the two reports?

The development board can talk to the Mazars report. One of the things we were faced with, which we spoke about earlier, was a time constraint for the making of the decision relating to the investment because of the contractual situation. We were told that the development board had commissioned the internal audit function - Mazars - to conduct an audit of the process. We confirmed to the development board that it was essential that this be concluded in time for the Government when it needed to make its decision. What we were seeking-----
Which was when?

The Government made its decision in December. What we were seeking was an assurance that everything was tied down in the process and that nothing had got into the process that should not have got in. The report from PwC will be a more in-depth exercise that examines what weaknesses within the process, if any, existed; how it happened; whether there was any means by which it could have been prevented; and whether there is any learning for the future. Both reports go over the same ground but one is quite distinct in its focus. One is trying to quality assure and confirm the outcome of the GMP process while the other is standing back and examining whether anything could have been done differently.

Could the Comptroller and Auditor General give his professional opinion regarding this? Would it be unusual for a project of this size to be on track one month and four months later, see an escalation of costs of €450 million?
That would be very concerning.
I know the Comptroller and Auditor General has not examined it-----
Not in that level of detail.

If he was to examine it, I presume that one of the things he would look at would be the role of individuals, the board and its responsibilities given that it is a legislative responsibility and whether the process is robust enough.

Why were the processes not robust enough to identify it long before they did?

That would certainly be the focus but I would not focus on whether individuals had some responsibility in that regard. My focus would be on functions, committees and whether those committees worked. The kind of things one would look for would be situations in which a committee was supposed to operate but did not operate or did not get some information it should have got and did not seek it. It could also be a case of determining, if an early mistake was made, the point at which the controls that were in place picked up on it. These are the kind of things one would look for. I expect that the work PwC has been commissioned to carry out, as reported here, will address some of those points.

I find it astonishing that we are on track one month and then, four months later, we are €450 million over and above what we predicted. It seems to have snowballed in a very short period of time. One would have to question the controls and processes which were put in place.

The question would be, if there had been some major change in the project, why did it occur? The question might also be were the controls that were in place operating properly from the get-go? Those would be the two possibilities.
Was the man from the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform, Mr. Quinn, on the finance sub-committee?
My understanding is that he was.
Therefore, theoretically he knew before June. He was in that group that reported to the board.
June was when the report-----

He knew before the whole board did, as Mr. Costello said earlier. I find it very disturbing that the head of procurement, who was on the board, knew about this. Although Mr. Breslin expects that communication would have been carried out through the normal governance structures, let us call a spade a spade, we know that is not how it works. He would have been talking to people. He works in the Department. He must have mentioned it. I do not buy the idea that information did not get out. I am serious concerned if the head of procurement knew about this and the Minister was not informed until August.
With respect, I believe the board acted in a collective and cohesive manner during a very difficult time.

I never said it did not. I just expressed my concern that the head of procurement in the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform knew about this and neither the Minister or Mr. Breslin, who is in charge of writing the cheques, did. It is really concerning. He was also chair of the finance sub-committee that reported. I am going backward to where I intended to go. Mr. Breslin is the Accounting Officer. He said that he does not absolve himself and that he takes responsibility. This is the fourth or fifth time I have been at committee proceedings on this issue with Mr. Breslin. He never says anything which there is nothing behind. I understand that he is the Accounting Officer but it seems very clear that he does not think the board was fit for purpose. Looking at its make-up and the way in which members were supposed to be appointed, it seems highly unusual that it would not include a specialist nurse who works in intensive care or, perhaps, somebody who had worked in Crumlin and seen the horrific conditions there or somebody who had worked in one of the other high-tech hospitals across the world about which we have spoken. I understand the Minister appointed the board, but its make-up seems to have been a recipe for disaster. I am very suspicious in respect of the gap between the escalation in costs becoming known and the board being reappointed in July.

I hear what the Deputy is saying. Obviously in formulating a board one has to come to a decision as to what the necessary competencies are. The framing of this board, which goes back to 2013, was based on the skills required to deliver the biggest construction project to be undertaken in the public sector, in light of the experience of the Mater site which did not get through the planning process. As Dr. Curtis has explained, detailed engagement processes were put in place with the client, the children's hospital group, but the expertise identified for the board were those required to deliver a major construction project - to get it through the planning process properly and to get it designed, procured and so on.
The project got through the planning process.
Yes.

The design seems to have been done incorrectly. The fees went up by 63%, so it did not really work out. As for the procurement, it seems very obvious that there were issues. To move on to something else, what size is the €500,000 office in square metres?
It is 2,500 sq. m.

It cost €500,000. Is there somebody who can do sums? The upper end of what one pays to fit out a corporate office is approximately €2,000 per metre square. Does this cost exceed that? Can anybody do the sums for me?
It is approximately a tenth of that cost.
The fit-out is relatively good value.
It is cheap and cheerful.
I am just pointing that out because I do not want to have a go at the witnesses all the time, just when absolutely necessary.
I thank the Deputy.

On BAM and this guaranteed maximum price to finish this project and produce a hospital, do we know BAM's turnover, margin, and profitability? The reason I am asking for these is because I am concerned about liquidity. I am concerned about what will happen if something goes wrong. I am getting concerned about these mechanical and electrical subcontractors. Who is going to fall on this? We have been guaranteed that the price will not go up unless we bring in a different VAT measure or change the scope, or if inflation in construction exceeds 4%, but if BAM goes bust with this project half-way out of the ground where will we go then? From looking at it, there are little indicators that things may not all be right.
We are very happy that the three main contractors are in a very robust situation. BAM is-----
How is happiness gauged in accountancy terms? What has Mr. Costello done to make himself happy about this?
We did robustness tests on the companies prior-----
When were they done?
Prior to their tendering.
That was a long time ago.
We also keep an eye on it on an ongoing basis.
What is an eye?
We look at their accounts-----
How often?
-----annually.
When did Mr. Costello last look at the accounts?
I looked at them this time last year.
A lot can change in a year.
There are certainly no signals. Usually, in the industry-----
There are no signals.
I mean-----
I must have imagined them when I looked at the figures.
I can tell the Deputy what I mean by that. If a company is headed into trouble there are signals a long time before its accounts are ready.
Are the mechanisms being used to test robustness the same mechanisms used in respect of the two companies that went bust during the project?
In fairness, they went bust ahead of-----
Was the same technique applied? Yes or no?
It is a very simple question. Was the same technique that is being used now applied to test the robustness of the two companies that went bust? Yes or no? It is very simple. Was the process changed?
I am trying to understand exactly what the question is.

I will make it a little bit clearer. Perhaps Mr. Costello does not understand. He says that he is testing to ensure that none of the companies is going to go bust so that we are not left with a half a hospital out of the ground. I asked when he last tested that and he told me that it was a year ago. I would argue that liquidity can change very quickly. We just need to look back to ten years ago in this country to see that. Mr. Costello obviously used certain ways to test the robustness of the companies. Two of them went into liquidation early on in the project. Are the same mechanisms being used to test the liquidity of the company that is now in charge? I do not think that is a difficult question.
In fairness, we did not actually contract with those companies. They had tendered-----
I have still not got the answer but I am willing to sit here until 9 o'clock tonight, so go for it. Are you using the same mechanism?
We use outside advisers for robustness and there are clear robustness tests around the suitability of a company.
Are the same external people using the same mechanism now as there were then?
It is quite a different situation now, in that we are in contracts with people. While it is important to be mindful of trends, there is not much we can do about it.
Part of your job is to deliver the project. If they go bust the hospital will not be finished.
Other than having early warnings we cannot do more as we are contracted with those people now. They are very strong companies. I hope this gives the Deputy comfort.

I am not overly comfortable about the situation but we will leave it at that. The Government contracts committee approved the change of contract type to a two-stage contract. Do we have minutes from that meeting? I understand there was a derogation for this process to be allowed. The two-stage process has led to an escalation of prices in other jurisdictions. When the Government contracts committee allowed this process to happen, did it ask any questions about this novel way of dong things or about the risks associated with it?

The development board would have been interrogated about its proposal and the board would have had to articulate what the business rationale was for going that route. In such a situation the committee would give a derogation.
That is what happened.

We formed a working group in 2014 which had membership from the Government construction contract committees. We worked through the two-stage procurement process and had meetings with the Government contracts committee, GCC, which are minuted. We also had presentations to the overall committee.

Does Mr. Pollock remember if they asked if this type of tendering process had increased costs in other jurisdictions? It seems like an obvious question to ask. Would it not be obvious to ask what the pitfalls were and why we had not always done things in this way?
The scale and complexity of this project were unique.
Unique to Ireland?
Unique to Ireland. We had previously discussed the design and build option.

I accept that the two-stage process was a good idea but it seems, from other jurisdictions and ours, to be fraught with escalating prices. I was wondering if a question was asked about the pitfalls of the two-stage process.
I was not in attendance at those meetings as they were attended by our procurement department but we have the minutes.
Are we back to Mr. Quinn again?
No, I am talking about within the executive.
Can the committee get an answer to the question?
We have minutes from the meetings.
Can I have the answer from them?
Yes. The Deputy can have the minutes.

A long time ago the health committee spoke about equipment. The word "equip" comes up in the list of costs, with a figure of €87.9 million. Is that to buy or lease equipment? Who decides that? A lot of corporations, even in retail and certainly in the HSE, do not own their equipment because the price of having the manpower, or womanpower, to service the equipment is an issue. They lease the photocopier or the MRI scanner and the contractor services it. Is that the model or are we buying stuff? I spent time on the health committee some years ago and I understood that the lease option was preferred from the point of view of long-term costs. With a lease a company gets a new product when the first is out of date. Is there another surprise coming down the tracks in relation to this?
The final decision has not been made on this. We are currently equipping the urgent care centre at Connolly Hospital.
If it has not been decided, why is there a figure of €87.9 million?
In our budget we have provided for these things to be procured traditionally by buying equipment. We are buying the equipment for Connolly Hospital and it is being installed.
Is the NHS doing that? Do the Dutch or the Swedes do that? My understanding is that there is normally a lease and maintenance arrangement.
International practice is moving towards managing equipment with services.
I remember discussing this with Professor Hardiman.
The development board has carried out a business case examination on using a managed equipment service.
It has decided that the better thing to do is buy the stuff.

The money is provided on the capital side if we do it conventionally. It would be novel in the Irish public sector to use a managed equipment service. My appetite for taking a novel approach and doing something for the first time is starting to dissipate in the case of this project.
My appetite for doing things differently from the rest of the world is also weakening.
We will look at it. We have the budget.

The health committee discussed at length how we pay and replenish equipment, as well as staff costs and other things. We all know what will happen.

The costs of the project went up by 46% but the contingency went up by only 31%. Is there a reason for that or is it just to try to make things look cheaper? Is the contingency fit for purpose, given the size of this project?
That is linked to the two-stage procurement process. Now that we have completed the GMP process-----
It is not as risky. Is that the point?
Risk has been reduced.
I thank the witnesses for their time.

There is a PricewaterhouseCoopers review of the escalation of costs relating to the new children's hospital. Everybody has been fixated on the escalation of the costs but they are only part of the story. The overall costs are the bigger story. From the meetings of the health committee to today's meeting, bits have been added on. There are many excuses for why this happened but, as Chairman of the Committee of Public Accounts, I am more concerned about how we get from where we are today to the completion of the project. I think this might be looked at to some extent in the review to which I referred. I would prefer, however, if PricewaterhouseCoopers had been commissioned to examine the €1.7 billion, rather than what has happened in the past four years. How valid is the figure of €1.7 billion? The Department has said it cannot confirm that the figure will not go over €2 billion and I know that nobody can answer that. The real concern of most people, however, is how high this could go. I would be more concerned to get assurances about what happens between now and the hospital being handed over as this is more relevant. Mistakes were made and learned from, such as missing things in the preliminary design, but it is more important to know how reliable is the estimate of €1.7 billion. Can Mr. Breslin comment on that? The Department should have commissioned a report on that.

We would be happy to reflect on that and we were going to do a separate exercise on sensitivity in parallel with the PricewaterhouseCoopers report.

Mr. Sullivan has engaged with PwC directly. I have no doubt that it will be looking at other projects and how this one stacks up against them. However, we can reflect on what we can get out of it and ask whether it covers the angles to which the Chairman is referring.

With regard to the terms of reference, there is a point that is relevant concerning the major residual risks and the robustness and completeness of the current arrangements. That is the most important thing and I ask that it be reconsidered. Telling us what happened three years ago is fine but it does not protect us for the future.
I am more interested in protecting the taxpayer from today on.
I agree, although there are many people interested in understanding what went wrong, whether something went wrong and who is responsible. Therefore, I think we have to combine the two.

That is important but the bigger risk for the taxpayer as of today concerns whether the amount involved stops at the €1.7 billion for which we are now on the hook or rises further. I would like more information on future-proofing the rest of the delivery under the contract.

On the flow of information, it appears from what Deputy Jonathan O'Brien was saying that there were clear indications of what was occurring from June 2017. With such a critical project, one would almost expect that there should have been a hotline if there was going to be a problem. It was the biggest project in the Department of Health and the flow seemed to be very slow. There was a reference to a response to a parliamentary question that the Department prepared and the Minister put on the record. The Department was not over-budget but it knew there was a problem. Perhaps there was not complete candour. The Department knew well there was a problem but was not saying there was a problem, and its reason for not acknowledging it was that it did not know its extent. There should have been a better flow of communication.

PwC will definitely look at the development board's processes under bullet point 2. I refer to establishing what was known, when it was known and by whom and to the reporting of relevant information from the project team to the relevant oversight and governance bodies. That goes to the heart of what Deputy Jonathan O'Brien was asking about. Which entity knew? Was it the design team? Was it Linesight? Was it the executives within the development board? Was it a committee of the board? Was it the board? How was it escalated?
I have a simple question. How many employees are there in the board?
What we do know is that it was over-budget by €200 million by late August. The reply to the parliamentary question in September did not indicate that.

It just stated that there was a budget. The Department almost indicated that because it did not know the extent of the problem overall, it decided not to mention it until it could give a figure. There should have been some indication that there was a potential problem, however. It would have been relevant given that the Oireachtas was discussing the budget on 14 October or 15 October and the Estimates for the coming year.

Also, it is a matter of the development board challenging the contractors so they do not simply accept a case that was made in commercial negotiations. It was a matter of continuing to challenge that robustly.

Mr. Breslin gets the point. I asked a question earlier in respect of which I need a figure. Mr. Breslin kind of skimmed over it. I want to know what will be the annual operating budget for the hospital when it is in full swing.
The figure compiled by Children's Health Ireland is €367 million. That is a 2023 figure. Obviously, that is subject to variation based on pay agreements and so on.
How does that tally with the cost of running Temple Street in Crumlin-----

It accounts for the three constituent hospitals, including Crumlin, but it also accounts for the fact that, this year, for example, we will be recruiting 173 additional staff to provide for the bringing on stream of the Connolly satellite centre.

Not that there is an issue. The last thing people want is these spanking new facilities not up and running. That has been the history of extensions to hospitals over the years. For the public record, what will be the cost of running the operation per year by comparison with that of running the existing children's hospital? What will the increase be? Given that everything is to be combined on one campus, and given all the new technology, equipment, heating systems and insulation, some are saying to me there should be a reduction in cost.

There will be some savings to be made but we know from access problems, waiting lists for paediatric care and so on that the capacity is going to be increased. I have mentioned some of the increases in capacity for day patients and outpatients. In total, there will be an increased budget. It will not all happen in 2022 when we open because are going to scale up, with new centres in Blanchardstown and Tallaght. Also, within the constituent hospitals, we will see a gradual move towards that higher figure. I would be happy to supply the Chairman with the current budgets of the three constituent hospitals and also the development budget for this year that we put aside for the Connolly satellite.

It is only a matter of providing a headline figure because other committees, systems and processes can interrogate this. I refer to headline figures, a bit like the €1.7 billion, just to give us an understanding. To my knowledge, the NDFA has a role in advising on all major capital infrastructure projects. We were involved with it regarding the Mater Hospital site. It seems to have disappeared. Why did the delegates not continue to engage it? What role could it possibly have played? It is meant to have a role. What happened? Why did it disappear off the pitch?

The NDFA was involved in the financial analysis of the robustness of the tenders for the design team. On capital projects like this, there is not a financial advisory role other than for specific cases. Where there is private finance, like there is with the PPP projects, obviously, the NDFA has a role in managing and being a financial adviser on an ongoing basis. In this case, there are specific issues on which we needed financial advice, such as the robustness of the tenderers, the design team and the contractors, and also in regard to preparing a business case.
If the NDFA has competence in that area, why was it not used to check the financial robustness of all the main contractors. Mr. Costello stated that there is some other method of doing it.
In that case, we used Ernst & Young.
The obvious question, from having listened to Deputy O'Connell earlier, concerns whether there is a bond in place if something major happens.
There is indeed.
What is the scale? What is the schedule of payments? Do they get any advance payments for work or is it for-----
No, it is measured on a monthly basis. It is certified works on a monthly basis, and that is the standard.
In arrears.
Yes.

If something happened to a major contractor with which there is direct involvement – there are a number of them – the cost of another contractor tendering and picking up the pieces would result in an additional cost. What kinds of performance bonds or completion bonds – there are different words for bonds – has the board in place?
There is a performance bond of €40 million.

In other words, if something happens the main contractor, the board has €40 million available to cover the costs of the project stopping, retendering and appointing a new contractor. Is that reasonable, from Mr. Costello's experience?
Hopefully it will not arise.
I understand that.
Again it goes back to what Deputy O'Connell asked. It is a question of making sure one is dealing with people who will stand up to scrutiny and deliver the project-----

Mr. Costello can understand the concern, particularly in view of what occurred with schools building projects. Fortunately, there were no advance payments in those cases. Had there been, we would be in a dreadful position. Does Mr. Costello understand there is heightened public concern regarding these issues?

In the overall discussion it is important, bearing in mind the skinny margins of the top ten contractors in the UK and the pushing of the risk down to the supply chain. Carillion went out of business. Interserve is at risk and Keir is really under pressure.
Sammon is gone.

Yes. Irrespective of what challenges and issues we have – they are substantial – if one of our big contractors, particularly our main contractor, were to go out of business, we would have a much greater problem than the one we are trying to deal with here because at least we have not spent the money yet and have control of what we are doing.
There is a lot of talk about the preliminary design. Who produced that?

The architect is BDP, and it is in partnership with Irish architecture firm O'Connell Mahon. The mechanical and electrical design was done by Arup and the civil structure was designed by O'Connor Sutton Cronin.

Mr. Costello might send us a note on that. The underestimation associated with the preliminary design seems to be a core issue. There is an argument not that costs escalated to the extent they did but that, to begin with, the figures given at an earlier stage were incorrect.

The comment has been made at the Committee of Public Accounts over the decades. There is often a tendency for public sector projects to go into the system with a low cost to get them approved and they eventually come to the point where they cannot be stopped and the costs escalate. We can think of many projects. It is almost the way the system works in a lot of cases. Does Mr. Breslin understand the criticism?
I absolutely agree it is something to be looked at.
It looks a bit like that.

The other thing is that over the past five years during this period, the inflation in the construction market was beyond what one would normally expect. It does not explain the extent of this but it is an environment where inflationary pressures are in existence.
When was the main contract signed? Was it early 2017?
It was signed in August 2017 and the contractor started works in October 2017.
So they were on site in October 2017. When was the detailed design completed because it was at that stage, you started to see the issues. When was the detailed design?
That works right through from when the contractor started in October until September, October and November. They were still closing down individual packages at that stage.
Approximately a year.
Correct.

To get on site a year early to show activity, we left ourselves wide open to having a contractor on site without a detailed design and now we are in the situation that when we do see the detailed design, the options are very limited. The witnesses can understand that scenario. It looks like that.
I understand where the Chairman is coming from and I think it is important for people to understand that the complete job was tendered in 2016.
Not the completed. There was no completed-----
The total project.
Yes.
Without the detailed design.
There were rates tendered for all elements of the work. At the end of the day, we are now applying the quantities that come from the completed design to the rates we had in 2016.
Did Mr. Costello revisit this? Was it the cheapest tender?
BAM was considerably the cheapest.

I think it was €120 million or €130 million below the others. In the public sector, there is another method of deciding which is the most economically advantageous price. It means if things go up like the PC sums or extra quantities come into play, a contractor might give the lowest price to do the basic work but when the extra items are factored in, it might not be the most economically advantageous. Now that the design is completed, if the Department was to rerun the tenders it got, based on the best economically advantageous contract, would the same contractor have got the contract? Does Mr. Costello understand my question?
Yes.
Was that done?
The answer is without any doubt at all.
The board has run the figures on that.
Yes.
It has.
Yes
Mr. Costello understands the question.
Yes. It is all based on rates and percentage mark-ups.
It would have won on both counts.
Yes.
It is probably no harm to clarify that.
No.

With regard to the contract, I know there is one and the board went in with the first 10% with the detailed design, which is about 10% of the final price, and the other 90% is subject to detailed design. Who decided that was the best way to go? The board could have taken a bit longer and tied it down before it started. Did the board feel rushed to get on site? Who made the decision to allow the contractor on site before the detailed design in respect of the overwhelming majority of the contract was completed? It was an enormous risk and it proved costly.

It is not that we came up with a bespoke model for doing two-stage tendering. In NEC contracts in the UK and internationally, two-stage tendering contracts are very similar to what we have done here. When we talk about changes here and engaging with the Government contracts committee, it was with regard to changes to the standard procurement rules that were in place at the time for public sector projects. In terms of a model for doing large complex projects internationally, what we are doing here very much aligns with it. At the time, if we had gone with the traditional model of design build, we would not have got anyone to tender for the job. We engaged-----
Is Mr. Costello saying the State decided to take all the risk? There was no risk-sharing here.

I think the Chairman will appreciate there is huge risk-sharing because in this case the contractors bid for this work very competitively. There is no way out of the competitive nature of it in the sense that the rates they have are still the rates we are using today.

I am nearly finished. I saw the financial report accounts. The European Investment Bank has provided €490 million to support the construction of a new children's hospital and the two paediatric outpatient and urgent care centres. What way does it work? Is the funding of this coming through borrowing? Who got that €490 million? What rate is it? Is it part of the NTMA's national debt management?
It is essentially a different way of the NTMA accessing debt and at an EIB rate.
At what rate?
I do not have the rate but it allows a more stable, structured, fixed long-term rate. It allows the EIB to invest in the project but via the NTMA and the Exchequer and not directly to the project.
So it comes to the NTMA but it goes into the overall pool of the NTMA. Is the Department going back to it now for the other almost €1.5 billion at that rate?
We will advise them of the development in the overall budget.

Does the NTMA have a view on a State agency for Ireland coming out and saying it has a project that will cost a number of million and would like to borrow €490 million through the European Investment Bank at that long-term rate for the major investment? It has been hearing in recent days that it is actually €1.4 billion or €1.7 billion depending on what one looks at. The next time Department representatives go out there will it believe any of the figures?
There are two things-----
Have we damaged our reputation?

Independently of the project, the State has entered into a commitment to repay it. The second thing is the EIB obviously wants to see its projects come to fruition so the State has come in and said it will finish this out. Those two things are in our favour. I agree with the Chairman that-----
If a business went to a bank to fund 60% of a project and then came back to the bank two years later and said the project had almost doubled in cost, it would not get a good reception.
It would get a worse reception if it went back to the bank and said, "I am marooned now and cannot finish the project."

I know but it has State backing. That will not happen. We are nearly finished. There is one other item. The phrase was used earlier before the last break when we were talking about a water sprinkler. It is in the last notes of the accounts. The note refers to events after the year end and it talks about the Bord Pleanála decision. It states, "A life-safety sprinkler system complying with BS EN 12845 shall be installed throughout the building." Is that a Bord Pleanála condition?
Yes.
What is a life-safety-----
It is fire sprinklers.
So it is not just water.
A mist is discharged. It is a water sprinkler system but it is throughout the entire building rather than the three upper floors about which we spoke earlier.
Is the BS EN 12845 the standard being operated?
Yes.
It is more extensive.
Exactly. It is the entire building - that is the point of note - rather than just the top three floors.

My final question to Mr. Breslin is about his serious concerns about what has happened. He cannot be happy. Is it too early to ask if he is happy to recommend that the board continues? The children's hospital has to continue.
The project has to continue. We have to complete this.
The project is sacrosanct. Nobody can say anything other than that.

If there are any weaknesses identified - the Minister is on the record - and action is needed to be taken, we will secure the project to ensure it delivers on the patient outcomes that are required. It does so now within a revised budget.

Mr. Breslin can understand that is why I am actually more concerned about the PwC report about where we are from today to completion. What has happened is tragic. We cannot change the past but we can, to some extent, control what will happen from now on.

The most important thing is there has to be some absolute assurance in place for the future costs. We have completed our extensive work. We started at the beginning looking for basic information. We thought that was where we were starting. The witnesses have appeared before the Joint Committee on Health. Perhaps it was looking at the escalation of costs but we were looking at the status of the project and the issue of completion. I did not get to follow the detailed conversation. If some of it has been unnecessarily repetitive, I apologise to the witnesses but everyone has a slightly different perspective. I hope it will bring a bit of clarity.

Our main concern at the Committee of Public Accounts is that this major project has gone financially off the rails. The Government is talking about light rail and broadband plans, which are all in the billions. If this is the level of governance in the system for capital projects we will be back here despite being told it was a once-off, unique project that could not happen anywhere else. They could be saying the same about the broadband plan in a few more years. I worry about the management of capital projects. This may not be the only one we need to be worried about.
I am actually finishing a special report on capital projects in the third level sector. There are lessons.
Obviously they did not transfer to the Department of Health. That is another concern.
It would generally be a different scale.

The witnesses will learn their lesson but none of them will ever be doing a national children's hospital again. It is supposed to be here for a century. The Department of Communications, Climate Action and Environment, the Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport or some other Government Department will be doing other projects with equivalent expenditure. That is why I get concerned. Where is the whole-of-Government learning? It is no good the Department learning if the guy doing the next project with another Department-----

It is important from the perspective of learning in the Department of Health has that we put in place something that will be there after we are gone. It is really important. I also agree with the point made about it being across Government. Attention is being paid across Government to the delivery of capital projects. We are very much informed by the work the Comptroller and Auditor General has done. This has particular features. Many capital projects within the public sector, as was said earlier, are delivered on time and on budget. We need to learn from all projects where risks were not managed and apply the learning across the public sector.
It is important lessons are learned but it is unfortunate they were very costly lessons for the taxpayer.
(Interruptions).
I appreciate there are members of the public present in the Public Gallery but it is an Oireachtas committee and only members of the Oireachtas may speak.
(Interruptions).

We are happy to speak to members of the public separately but we will conclude the meeting now. I thank those present in the Public Gallery for watching, learning and feeding back into the Committee of Public Accounts. If they feel we have something to contribute to the process or if they want to come back through the Committee of Public Accounts with an observation, we would be happy to address it down the road.

I thank all our witnesses from the national paediatric hospital development board, the Department of Health and the HSE and the Comptroller and Auditor General and his staff for their attendance. This is the witnesses' fourth appearance at an Oireachtas committee in a fortnight. I thank them for their forbearance. I am sure they are quite exhausted from coming into the committee rooms but it is such a big project, it was inevitable this was going to happen. That is all I will say.

Our next meeting will be on Thursday, 7 February 2019 when we will deal with the Appropriation Accounts 2017, Vote 1 - President's Establishment and Vote 2 - Department of the Taoiseach. The following session will deal with Vote 3 - Office of the Attorney General, Vote 5 - Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions and Vote 6 - Office of the Chief State Solicitor.
The witnesses withdrew.
The committee adjourned at 5.04 p.m. until 9 a.m. on Thursday, 7 February 2019.
Joint Oireachtas Committee on Finance, Public Expenditure and Reform, and Taoiseach

The Joint Committee met at 10:00

MEMBERS PRESENT:

Deputy Joan Burton, Senator Paddy Burke, Deputy Paul Murphy, Senator Rose Conway-Walsh, Senator Gerry Horkan, Senator Kieran O'Donnell.

DEPUTY JOHN MCGUINNESS IN THE CHAIR.
The joint committee met in private session until 10.28 a.m.
Business of Joint Committee
Before we deal with the main business of the meeting, as agreed in private session, members who wish to comment on the nurses' action may do so.

It is very important that all committees and particularly this one express solidarity with the nurses. None of the thousands of nurses who were on the picket line yesterday wished to be there. They wanted to be delivering treatments within a safe system. That is the key to the recruitment and retention issue. We cannot expect nurses to work under the present terms and conditions. I plead with the Minister and the Taoiseach to intervene to sort this out. I am very mindful of the almost 25,000 patients, some of whom have waited years and months to get their treatment, who had their appointments cancelled yesterday. That is not right in a State like this and we have to do everything we possibly can to stop it happening. I am also aware that today the psychiatric nurses are refusing to go on overtime, which is absolutely within their right. This highlights the chaos within the system. The situation will escalate unless the Government intervenes, and it needs to do so now.

The Government will have to intervene at some stage anyway. Those involved will have to sit down and work this out. It should happen sooner rather than later before other appointments have to be cancelled. I urge everyone who has something in their remit to be able to change this to change it. I commend the nurses on their bravery. It was not an easy thing for them to do knowing all those appointments, operations and procedures would be cancelled yesterday. They do not want to be on the picket lines and certainly I do not want to see them on the picket lines.

It is a good idea to have this brief session. The Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, Deputy Donohoe, is coming in to us next week. I would hope that by the time he comes in the situation is resolved and that the Government and the HSE have given a meaningful indication that they are willing to move substantially on the question of pay restoration and pay parity. If the Government does not do that, then it will be making a major mistake.

I was on four different picket lines yesterday. The public support is phenomenal, for example, the number of people in cars beeping to express their support and so on. The determination of the nurses and midwives to continue with their just struggle if there are no substantial concessions is striking. They will go ahead with the two days of strike next week and that will cause even more disruption. Obviously the nurses and midwives do not want to do that but they have no choice. It will go ahead next week.

The argument of the Government is that it cannot afford to pay them, etc. That does not get far with the nurses and midwives or the general public. One thing I intend to ask the Minister next week relates to the amount of money paid to the junior bondholders who refused to get burnt before Christmas. The amount is precisely what it would take, according to the Government, to pay the pay claim of the nurses and midwives. The Government is able to find the money for the bondholders but cannot find it for our health service.

There is broad public support because people understand that nurses are on the front line of an underfunded and what is in many respects a disastrous health service. The various health professionals in the health service are the good thing about the health service when people interact with it. People understand the difficult circumstances they are in. People understand that a win for the nurses would be a win for all workers and that it would be a step towards the kind of investment that we need in building a national health service in this country. I hope that we do not have to get answers from the Minister next week, but if we do, then we should be prepared for questioning and so on.

I welcome the fact that the Minister is coming in next week. I would hope that by the time he comes in this issue will be resolved. Those involved have no choice but to go back to the negotiating table. I hope they do that immediately and bring a resolution to the whole issue.

The purpose of giving members the opportunity this morning to air their views is because the committee deals with public expenditure and reform. Part of the committee remit is to cover the agreements on public pay. Having witnessed the nurses working at first-hand, any of us would agree that they are at the coal-face, that they are understaffed, that the pay situation has not been what it should be and that it has been allowed to drag on for a long number of years. This House has overlooked the real issues in the context of the nurses. There has been no real debate about public pay in this House, but there should be.

Next Tuesday we will have the Minister before us and we can deal directly with him in respect of these matters. I was on the picket line yesterday in two different hospitals. The people there were talking about pay restoration, pay parity and the conditions of their employment. They brought to my attention the health and safety issues on many of the wards in the hospitals I went to and in many others throughout the country. They are safety issues and staffing issues. It is clear from the messages being sent from Irish nurses working abroad that they would prefer to be at home. I was struck by some of the comments from those who came back. They say they have come back from a different health service to one that is way behind the required standards. It gives us the opportunity next Tuesday to highlight these matters.

I will make two final points about the patients on the waiting list and those who have been cancelled. I would ask them to bear with the situation. I know that it is difficult, but at the same time this is about a long-term issue in terms of safety and pay.

When I was on the picket line yesterday at St. Luke's General Hospital in Kilkenny some of the nurses actually went into the hospital to relieve some of their colleagues and deal with some emergency issues that arose. It is not as if they are ignoring their patients – they are not. The strike is about patients and nurses and it should be resolved. The politics of this House is such that it is, in my opinion, ignoring the issues at hand. There should be a debate and discussion about the whole thing and resolution rather than it going any further. I thank the members for their contributions. We can now move to the next item.
Scrutiny of EU Legislative Proposals

The joint committee agreed that EU proposals COM (2018) 821, COM (2018) 832, COM (2018) 812 and COM (2018) 819 do not warrant further scrutiny. Full details of the decision will be published on the committee website.
Credit Union Advisory Committee: Discussion

We will now discuss the final report of the credit union advisory committee implementation group. I welcome all the guests this morning. Mr. Corr is from the Department of Finance. Mr. Farrell is from the Irish League of Credit Unions. Mr. Kevin Johnson is from the Credit Union Development Association. Mr. Tim Molan is from the Credit Union Managers Association.
